qas.question: Who wrote about the great pestilence in 1893?
What did Gasquet think the plague was?

answers.text: some form of the ordinary Eastern or bubonic plague

qas.question: When did the second edition of Gasquet's book come out?
What did Gasquet's book blame the plague on?
What is another plague thought to have spread the same way?

answers.text: the Justinian plague that was prevalent in the Eastern Roman Empire from 541 to 700 CE.

qas.question: When was Francis Aidan Gasquet born?
When did the bubonic plague begin in Europe?
What was the Justinian plague epidemic called?
In what year was the Eastern Roman Empire established?

context: The historian Francis Aidan Gasquet wrote about the 'Great Pestilence' in 1893 and suggested that "it would appear to be some form of the ordinary Eastern or bubonic plague". He was able to adopt the epidemiology of the bubonic plague for the Black Death for the second edition in 1908, implicating rats and fleas in the process, and his interpretation was widely accepted for other ancient and medieval epidemics, such as the Justinian plague that was prevalent in the Eastern Roman Empire from 541 to 700 CE.
